title: Ketan Patel

fields.name: Ketan Patel
fields.known_for: Co-founder and CEO of Greater Pacific Capital; founder and chair of the Force for Good Initiative; lead of UNCTAD-linked Future Capital initiative; publications on geopolitics, technology and capital allocation
fields.alma_mater: London School of Economics; City University Business School (MBA)
fields.notable_works: The Master Strategist; Who knows wins
fields.organization: Greater Pacific Capital; Force for Good Initiative

lead:
'''Ketan Patel''' (born February 1962)<ref name="R186" /> is a British investor, strategist and author. He is the chief executive and co-founder of the private equity firm ''Greater Pacific Capital'' (GPC) and the founder and chair of the Force for Good Initiative, which publishes research on capital allocation, technology and sustainable development.<ref name="R147" /><ref name="R187" /><ref name="R146" />

Patel served as lead of the ''Future Capital'' initiative convened by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), the UN Office for Partnerships and the World Academy of Art and Science, focused on aligning finance with the Sustainable Development Goals; UNCTAD described him as having substantial international experience and relationships in the finance sector.<ref name="R196" /><ref name="R195" /> He has published peer-reviewed research on great-power transitions and climate policy pathways in journals including ''Frontiers in Political Science'' and ''Frontiers in Environmental Economics'', and has published commentaries through Reuters.<ref name="R174" /><ref name="R197" /><ref name="R188" />

Patel is the author of ''The Master Strategist'' (2005) and ''Who Knows Wins'' (1996).<ref name="R207" /><ref name="R201" />

sections.heading: Early life and education
sections.wikitext: In a 2005 profile, ''The Independent'' reported that Patel studied at the London School of Economics and City University Business School.<ref name="R58" /> The UK Companies House register lists Patel's date of birth as February 1962 and his nationality as British.<ref name="R186" /> Biographical notes published by Greater Pacific Capital and the Force for Good Initiative state that he earned a BSc in Economics from the London School of Economics and an MBA from City University Business School and that he is a qualified accountant; the same sources state that he holds a postgraduate degree in neuroscience from King's College London.<ref name="R62" /><ref name="R190" />

sections.heading: Career
sections.wikitext:
===Early career===
After qualifying as an accountant, Patel worked at KPMG and later joined Goldman Sachs.<ref name="R58" /> A 2005 profile in ''The Independent'' described him as having been head of strategy at Goldman Sachs before leaving the firm to establish his own consultancy and investment business.<ref name="R58" /> Publisher and conference biographies have described him as having led Goldman Sachs' Strategic Group and referred to him as the firm's "chief futurologist".<ref name="R190" /><ref name="R194" />

===Greater Pacific Capital===
Patel is the co-founder and chief executive of the private equity firm Greater Pacific Capital (GPC).<ref name="R147" /><ref name="R187" /> The UK Companies House register lists him as a designated member of Greater Pacific Capital LLP since April 2005.<ref name="R186" /> Business Standard reported that Greater Pacific Capital acquired a stake in Indian investment bank Edelweiss Capital as part of its early India- and China-focused investment strategy.<ref name="R203" /> Media coverage of GPC has also included reporting on an India-focused fundraise and portfolio investments in education technology, electric vehicles and artificial intelligence.<ref name="R147" /><ref name="R150" /><ref name="R151" /><ref name="R153" />

===Force for Good Initiative===
Reuters has described Patel as the founder and chairman of Force for Good, which it says was established to support the UN Secretary-General's roadmap for sustainable development and examined and engaged 125 global financial institutions and 100 technology companies in its research programmes.<ref name="R187" /><ref name="R188" /> Force for Good publishes report series including ''Capital as a Force for Good'' and ''Technology as a Force for Good''.<ref name="R178" /><ref name="R179" /> An acknowledgement section for the ''Capital as a Force for Good'' project lists UNCTAD and the UN Office for Partnerships as hosts and names Patel as lead for the report, and lists participating financial institutions in the project.<ref name="R204" /> Coverage by the International Institute for Sustainable Development's SDG Knowledge Hub summarized findings from the technology report and its relevance to the SDGs.<ref name="R180" />

===Institutional and advisory roles===
UNCTAD has reported that Patel was lead of the Future Capital initiative, which was convened as a UN working group to develop recommendations on changing the way capital and finance are allocated in support of the 2030 Agenda; UNCTAD described Patel as a participant with substantial international experience and relationships in the finance sector who was asked to define and lead the initiative's finance-focused working group.<ref name="R195" /><ref name="R196" /> Patel has served as a trustee of the World Academy of Art and Science and has published with its journal ''Cadmus''.<ref name="R176" /> He is listed as a member of the advisory board of the United Nations at LSE programme (LSE IDEAS) in his capacity as CEO of the Force for Good Initiative.<ref name="R193" /> He is listed as a member of the SDSN Europe Senior Working Group on the European Green Deal and the SDGs.<ref name="R198" /> In 2025 he participated in the Maryam Forum summit on social and economic development in Bahrain.<ref name="R200" />

sections.heading: Ideas and contributions
sections.wikitext:
Patel's published work has focused on systemic risk and transition in the international order, with particular emphasis on the interaction of geopolitics, technology and capital allocation.

===Great-power transitions and the international order===
In a peer-reviewed article in ''Frontiers in Political Science'', Patel and co-authors argued that major powers tend to pass through identifiable life-cycle phases and assessed implications for U.S. strategic positioning and alliance structures.<ref name="R174" />

===Sustainable development finance and capital allocation===
In ''Cadmus'', Patel and co-authors argued that meeting the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is constrained less by the absolute availability of capital than by capital allocation mechanisms, incentives and risk pricing.<ref name="R161" /> In Reuters commentaries, Patel has argued that scaling proven solutions and mobilising capital at commercial scale are central to closing SDG funding gaps.<ref name="R188" /><ref name="R189" /> Stefan Brunnhuber later described the ''Cadmus'' paper as a "seminal" and "highly novel" contribution in an article responding to it.<ref name="R184" />

===Climate transition policy and pathways===
In a 2024 perspective article in ''Frontiers in Environmental Economics'', Patel and a co-author discussed the implications of COP28 for climate transition scenarios and socioeconomic pathways.<ref name="R197" />

===Global turbulence and polycrisis frameworks===
In 2025, Patel co-authored a series of ''Cadmus'' articles proposing conceptual frameworks for understanding what they termed "global turbulence" and policy responses to interlinked crises across security, development and governance.<ref name="R176" /><ref name="R175" />

===Cognitive sovereignty and information-era security===
A 2025 SSRN preprint by Patel examined what it termed "cognitive empires" and the strategic implications of algorithmic influence and AI systems for autonomy and security.<ref name="R177" />

===Technology and development pathways===
In Force for Good reports, Patel and collaborators have argued that digital technologies could materially accelerate progress toward sustainable development targets when paired with governance and investment frameworks.<ref name="R179" /><ref name="R180" />

sections.heading: Influence and reception
sections.wikitext:
Publisher material for ''The Master Strategist'' includes endorsement quotations attributed to Nelson Mandela, Nandan Nilekani and Nobuyuki Idei.<ref name="R206" /><ref name="R181" /> Speaker biographies for Patel at events including a Z/Yen Group webinar and the Doha Forum have described the book as having a foreword by Nelson Mandela.<ref name="R194" /><ref name="R191" /><ref name="R192" /> A review of the book appeared in the ''IMFO'' journal (Institute of Municipal Finance Officers).<ref name="R185" />

In academic and policy-adjacent forums, Patel's work on SDG finance has been cited by other authors in ''Cadmus''; for example, Stefan Brunnhuber described Patel and co-authors' SDG-financing paper as "seminal" and "highly novel" in an article responding to its argument.<ref name="R184" /> Patel has also published commentaries through Reuters on the SDGs and global development finance.<ref name="R188" /><ref name="R189" />

UNCTAD reporting on the Future Capital initiative described its draft work as "unprecedented" in defining activities that could make an entity or industry a "force for good" and described the project as having potential to support UN work on advancing investment in the SDGs.<ref name="R196" />

sections.heading: Personal life
sections.wikitext: A 2005 profile in ''The Independent'' noted that Patel lived in London and described his interest in meditation and long-distance running.<ref name="R58" />

sections.heading: Selected works
sections.wikitext:
* ''Who knows wins: using information to create and sustain strategic advantage'' (Jordans, 1996).<ref name="R201" /><ref name="R208" />
* ''The Master Strategist: Power, Purpose and Principle'' (Hutchinson, 2005).<ref name="R207" /><ref name="R183" />
* ''The Master Strategist: Power, Purpose and Principle in Action'' (Arrow, 2007).<ref name="R181" /><ref name="R183" />
* "COP28 and its impact on the shared socioeconomic pathways" (with Chris Hansmeyer), ''Frontiers in Environmental Economics'' (2024).<ref name="R197" />
* "American hegemony at a critical juncture, lessons from history's great powers" (with Christian Hansmeyer, Nandan Desai and Aditya Ajit), ''Frontiers in Political Science'' (2025).<ref name="R174" />
* "Sources and Solutions for Global Turbulence" (with Garry Jacobs), ''Cadmus'' (2025).<ref name="R176" />
* "Turbulent Times: A Framework for Navigating Global Crisis Through Conscious Transformation" (with Christian Hansmeyer), ''Cadmus'' (2025).<ref name="R175" />
* "Funding the Sustainable Development Goals is Not a Challenge of Sufficient Capital" (with Christian Hansmeyer, Nandan Desai and Aditya Ajit), ''Cadmus'' (2025).<ref name="R161" />
* "The Rising Age of Cognitive Empires: Colonising the Mind" (preprint), SSRN (2025).<ref name="R177" />
* "How to fix the financing for the Sustainable Development Goals" (commentary), Reuters (2023).<ref name="R189" />
* "To make a difference, tech needs to be a force for good" (commentary), Reuters (2025).<ref name="R188" />

sections.heading: Further reading
sections.wikitext:
* Nissel, Jason (29 May 2005). "Ketan Patel and Thomas Friedman: Just stop the world, so the West can get off". ''The Independent''.<ref name="R58" />
* "Changing the way capital and finance are allocated". UN Trade and Development (UNCTAD) (4 December 2020).<ref name="R196" />
* "Greater Pacific Capital hits first close of $300 million in $700 million India-focused fund". ''Mint'' (6 August 2018).<ref name="R147" />
* "Greater Pacific picks up 20% in Edelweiss Cap". ''Business Standard'' (15 February 2013).<ref name="R203" />
* "Force for Good Report Explores Role of Technology in Helping Reach SDGs". SDG Knowledge Hub (International Institute for Sustainable Development) (2 February 2023).<ref name="R180" />

external_links.label: SSRN – The Rising Age of Cognitive Empires

notability_signals: UNCTAD coverage of Future Capital working group naming Patel as initiative lead (2019–2020)
Reuters author and commentary pages publishing Patel's opinion pieces (2023–2025)
Peer-reviewed publications in Frontiers in Political Science (2025) and Frontiers in Environmental Economics (2024)
Business press coverage of Greater Pacific Capital fundraises and investments (e.g., Mint; Business Standard)
Publisher pages with prominent endorsement quotations for The Master Strategist (Penguin UK)
gaps_to_fill: Birthplace and early-life details from reliable independent sources (BLP completeness).
At least two additional substantial independent profiles (major newspaper/magazine/industry profiles) synthesizing Patel’s career and influence, beyond deal and event coverage.
Independent coverage of the Force for Good Initiative’s governance and real-world impact (beyond its own reports and press releases).
Verification of any claim that The Master Strategist contains a foreword by Nelson Mandela via book front matter or an authoritative bibliographic record.
Precise dates and transcript/page anchors for cited conference appearances where used for substantive claims.

revision_log.run_summary: Reconciled two draft versions into a single Wikipedia-style BLP draft emphasizing independently sourced notability: strengthened the lead with UNCTAD, Reuters and peer-reviewed publication anchors; expanded career coverage with UNCTAD Future Capital role and additional independent business press coverage; corrected and added publication metadata; and tightened reception to attributed publisher praise and independent review references. Removed or avoided promotional/unsourced claims per blueprint guidance.

added.what: Expanded to summarize primary roles and publication record with citations.
Added sourced narrative: KPMG/Goldman Sachs background (Independent, 2005), GPC coverage, and Force for Good report leadership; added independent coverage via IISD SDG Knowledge Hub.
Converted quote-led text into framework subsections supported by peer-reviewed and journal sources; added SSRN preprint coverage and Cadmus response article.
Added publisher-hosted endorsement quotations attribution and an independent review citation; added Cadmus response characterizing SDG paper.
Expanded and reconciled bibliographic entries, distinguishing 2005 Hutchinson hardback, 2007 Arrow paperback, and 2011 e-book editions.
Curated independent and institutional sources for readers.

modified.what: Added/updated occupation and known_for fields; removed unsupported nationality category.

removed.what: Removed due to insufficient independent sourcing and to reduce BLP risk.

quote_bank.quote_text: If you add to the purpose of every tech company, all of a sudden you have a moral purpose, you have something that could be hugely profitable, because your technology reaches a customer base that (previously) was not profitable.
quote_bank.speaker: Ketan Patel
quote_bank.speaker_credential: Described by Reuters as running the Force for Good Foundation
quote_bank.context: Quoted by Reuters in a report on CES adopting a social theme.

quote_bank.quote_text: A series of interlinked crises, from armed conflicts and energy shocks to deglobalization, climate change, and economic turbulence, risk negatively impacting the global economy, geopolitical stability, and societies across the world.
quote_bank.speaker: Technology as a Force for Good report (Force for Good Initiative)
quote_bank.context: Report framing of polycrisis and systemic transition.

quote_bank.quote_text: Technology can reduce the cost of achieving the SDGs by as much as USD 55 trillion, enabling 103 of the 169 SDG targets.
quote_bank.speaker: SDG Knowledge Hub (IISD) summary of Force for Good report
quote_bank.context: Independent coverage summarizing Force for Good report claims.

quote_bank.quote_text: Brunnhuber described the SDG-financing paper by Patel and co-authors as "seminal" and "highly novel".
quote_bank.speaker: Stefan Brunnhuber
quote_bank.context: Response article discussing SDG financing argument.

claim_ledger.claim: Patel is CEO and co-founder of Greater Pacific Capital.
Patel chairs the Force for Good Initiative.
Patel studied at the London School of Economics and City University Business School.
Patel and co-authors published a peer-reviewed article in Frontiers in Political Science on U.S. hegemony and lessons from historical great powers.
Patel and co-authors argued in Cadmus that SDG financing is constrained by allocation mechanisms rather than absolute capital availability.
